Award.AwardTitle: Build and Broaden: The Long-Term Impact of COVID-19 in Hispanic Communities in the Tri-State Area

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is a conference that serves as a forum to discuss and advance scientific understanding of the long-term impact of COVID-19 pandemic on Latino communities in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut. In addition to the disproportionate health impacts of COVID-19 on Latino communities, the pandemic has triggered an economic recession and educational privation across the United States that have also excessively affected Latino communities in the Tri-State area. In the conference, social and behavioral scientists from a wide range of disciplines, featuring scholars from regional Hispanic Serving Institutions, share their emerging research on the interconnected dynamics of the transformation in community contexts, access to healthcare, and educational outcomes in Hispanic communities due to the pandemic. The knowledge developed from this conference will help decision makers and community leaders develop an in-depth understanding of the impact of the pandemic on Latino communities. <br/><br/>This conference broadens participation by Latina and Latino scholars and scholars that teach and do research with Latino communities in the advancement of knowledge and understanding on health, economic, and educational impacts of the pandemic. The conference is organized to institutionalize social networks across regional Hispanic Serving Institutions. The thematic areas of the conference include (1) health disparities, (2) community structures, and (3) educational processes. Each of the first three panels highlights one of these central themes, while the second-day panel focuses on building foundational connections across the thematic areas. The conference features three levels of dissemination: a special journal issue to be shared with the academic community, the participation of community-based organizations and policymakers in the conference; and a broadcast and digital repository of researcher snapshots and conference proceedings for the broader public.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Montclair State University hosted The Inaugural Build & Broaden Conference: Long-Term Impacts of Covid-19 on Latino Communities in the Tri-State Area, a three-day conference that gathered scholars, community organizers, and government workers from sociology, education, psychology, public health, and political science. The major goal was to advance knowledge on how Latino communities in New Jersey, New York, and Connecticut have been impacted during the COVID-19 pandemic through: 1) bringing together social and behavioral scientists from a wide range of disciplines from regional Hispanic Serving Institutions, 2) creating panels and a poster session that disseminated information about emerging research on the interconnected dynamics of the transformation in community contexts, access to healthcare, and educational outcomes in Hispanic communities due to the pandemic, 3) centering a panel on community organizations from the region that support the Latino communities in these contexts, and 4) bringing together government officials from the region to discuss the impact of the pandemic on the Latinx community.

The Inaugural Build & Broaden Conference: Long-Term Impacts of Covid-19 on Latino Communities in the Tri-State Area took place August 15-17, 2021 at Montclair State University in Montclair, NJ. The conference was held on-line and in-person, and over half of the participants were Latinx. Participants were from the three states in the region. Participants engaged shared their research, engaged in discussion, shared ideas, addressed opportunities and challenges to support the Latinx communities after the pandemic.

To achieve these objectives, we designed strategic panels and a keynote. The three days of the conference involved five panel discussions on public health, education, and immigrant experiences of Latinx communities in these three states. A featured panel that kicked off the conference was the State of the States, which set the stage for the rest of the conference by discussing the pressing concerns and needs of Latinx communities in these states post-COVID. Another key panel focused on the role of community-based organizations that are responding to the pandemic in Latinx communities in these three states.

The conference advanced social scientific discovery on the impacts of COVID-19 on the Latino communities in Connecticut, New Jersey, and New York by sharing emergent interdisciplinary knowledge. The qualitative and quantitative research centered Latinx sociology of health, work, education, and race-ethnicity, drawing from scholars in sociology, education, psychology, public health, and political science. Presenters developed a consensus that COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated how structural inequalities affect Latino communities. Panels with different themes emphasized different mechanisms of how the pandemic has affected certain Latino communities. The knowledge developed from this conference will help decision makers and community leaders develop an in-depth understanding of the impact of the pandemic on Latino communities.
